Award.AwardTitle: Neotectonic History of the Eastern California Shear Zone based on U-Pb/U-Th Dating of Syntectonic Precipitates
Award.AbstractNarration:
The likelihood of an earthquake to occur at a specific place and time depends on a number of parameters that are difficult to constrain. For example, short-term estimates of strain rates that exceed longer-term fault slip rates are one parameter that we consider to increase the risk for near-future release of accumulating strain. At many active plate boundaries, there is a general agreement between modern and the long-term geological constraints on crustal deformation rates. However, in the Eastern California Shear Zone (ECSZ), southern California, the geological estimations are half of those suggested by the geodetic data. Notwithstanding, the long-term geological record of fault-slip rates is based on a collection of palaeoseismological data from the past 50,000 years, which compared to the approximately 20 Ma of fault activity in the ECSZ can only offer a very partial understanding of long-term faulting processes. This study will combine microstructural analysis, isotopic and geochemical constraints, and advanced in situ absolute (SHRIMP-RG) dating techniques to study the timing and formation mechanisms of syn-tectonic opal precipitates from the ECSZ, with the aim of developing a new approach for directly dating fault activity, and to ultimately establish a long-term record of fault activity. Specifically, this project will seek to determine (1) the fluid source and formation mechanisms of fault-related opals; (2) the timing of opal precipitation and the temporal association with brittle deformation events (e.g., syn-tectonic/post-tectonic). Outcomes of this project include the development of a new approach for (1) direct dating of paleo-earthquakes using in situ SHRIMP-RG Th/U and U-Pb dating techniques applied to fault-related material; (2) dating fault activity from initiation (millions of years) to present time. Important anticipated outcomes from this case study on the Mojave Desert segment of the ECSZ include long-term constraints on the timing of initiation and history of fault activity that will help to resolve discrepancies between estimated long- and short-term strain accumulation rates.

Given the recent and devastating earthquakes, there is a growing public concern that high-magnitude earthquakes are more frequent today than in the past, along with a demand for more accurate prediction. Thus, a major goal of this project is to provide up-to-date palaeoseismological data to both the scientific community and the general public. This project will develop a new high-spatial resolution dating techniques for fault related materials that will then be available to the scientific community through two shared analytical facilities. Data from this project will be contributed to the U.S. Geological Survey paleoseismic database.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reconstruction of long-term fault activity is required to understand the mechanisms for fault behavior, and by extension, to improve earthquake hazard assessments. Increasing evidence for temporal variations in strain accumulation rates suggest that strain rates are non-uniform over geological timescales, impairing evaluation of earthquake recurrence intervals and hence the hazards associated with a particular fault system. Fault interactions, changes in loading in the deep crust, and static stress transfer in the upper crust are some of the proposed mechanisms driving non-uniform strain rates; however, the lack of long-term records of fault activity has limited our ability to differentiate between mechanisms. To address this problem, we developed a new method for constructing long-term records of fault activity based on in-situ U-Pb dating of fault-related chemical precipitates (i.e., opal and calcite). Specifically, the method combines spatial analysis of microstructures with geochronology using an in situ high spatial resolution (ca. 50 to 100 micrometers) secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) to determine the uranium-lead (U-Pb) and uranium-thorium (230Th-U) ages of fault-related precipitates.

We applied this new method to the seismically active Mojave Desert segment of the Eastern California Shear Zone (ECSZ); (Fig. 1). Here, the exact timing of fault initiation has major implications for the role of the ECSZ in the development of the Pacific-North American plate. The ECSZ represents an ideal area within which to test the approach because there is an observed discrepancy between short-term and long-term estimates of strain accumulation rates. Temporal constraints on the activity of secondary faults from this study also provide important observations regarding fault initiation, longevity and activity.  

We found that faulting within the ECSZ initiated between 12 and 2.5 Ma, consistent with previous estimates of 12 Ma. We also dated multiple deformation events within a single structure (3 at most). These results indicate that fault reactivation occurs over million-year timescales (between 5.8 to 0.4 Myr). In addition, relative probabilities of dated deformation events suggest that the fault activity within the ECSZ has fluctuated over the past 10 Myr, with activity peaking around 1.5 Ma and decreasing to the present. These observations demonstrate that faults in the ECSZ are long-lived structures with a complex history of activity. As a result, their reactivation and slip histories cannot be simply extrapolated from geological records of the past 50 kyr. Applications of the U-Pb dating technqiue thus offers a unqiue approach for determinining  the mechanisms contributing to non-uniform strain rates in the upper crust.

Additional work on the project has included evaluation of strain from observations of calcite twinning, paired with (230Th-U) geochronology, and data on the oxygen and carbon isotope composition and rare earth element concentrations of fault precipitates to differentiate the fluid sources.

Intellectual Merit: We developed a new method for directly determining the history of fault zones using in situ SHRIMP-RG 230Th/U and U-Pb dating of fault-related precipitates and provided the first record of fault activity extending from initiation (millions of years) to the present time. An  important outcome from our case study of the Mojave Desert segment of the ECSZ is the development of long-term constraints on both the timing of fault initiation and the frequency of fault activity. Such constraints are required to that will help to resolve discrepancies between estimated long- and short-term strain accumulation rates.
